title: donald clark a tribute
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsDonald Clark was for  years the convivial, larger-than-le host at The George Hotel in Inveraray, a notable bon viveur and one of the most colourful characters in Argyll. He died aged  on January  after a short illness.Latterly, his mobility hampered by a leg injury, he would sit in the corner of The George public bar on an over-sized carved wooden stool. From his throne he dispensed news, advice and anecdotes – albeit not always historically accurate. His inimitable irony, perfectly-timed humour and the occasional reprimand to a wayward customer were all fuelled by a generous glass.As former president of the Scottish Licensed Trade Association and Keeper of the Quaich, Donald knew the intricacies of the business intimately from personal experience. His taste was eclectic and his appetite substantial, extending from Dom Perignon and Saint-Émilion Grand Cru to Tennent’s lager and Glen Dronach single malt. On a hot day he’d have an icy Martini or a gin and tonic, proportionately scaled up in a pint glass. Being askedhe had time for a quick ‘small one’, he would reply: #I’ll decide the size for myself,you don’t mind.#The records suggest that his frequent claim to be Scottish Slimmer of the Year, after getting his weight down from  stone to  stone, was fancul.Big D, as he was often called, was fastidious about standards in the little public bar, training his regulars to clear tables of empty glasses and plates promptly, and to keep the log fire stoked on winter evenings.If one of his regulars turned up untypically well-dressed, Donald would raise an eyebrow in mild surprise:  #What’s the occasion for the suit   A funeral   Your latest marriage   Or has your court case come up #In summer, an erratic stream of foreign tourists would have their first encounter with a Scottish pub, standing in the doorway bewildered as to what happens next – sit or stand  Fight their way to the mobbed bar or go to a table and wait for the non-existent waitress  Donald would call them over to his corner and was soon plying them with drinks, food and conversation, not infrequently paying the entire bill for his astonished guests.When a tourist asked him about the quaint red GPO telephone box in Church Square, he told them: #We have the fastest modern communications here – telephone, teletext and tell Donald.#Donald was a Francophile and loved his summers in Collioure, where #Le Grand Ecossais# was almost as well-known as in Argyll. A fixture of the local bars and restaurants, and frequently crossing the border to patronise Spanish hostelries, he revelled in the region’s seafood, wine and culture.His hobbies included cooking, opera, reading and lively conversation on a sweeping range of topics from local history to civil engineering. His knowledge was genuinely wide, but when occasionally encountering someone with a superior command of the topic in question, he would quickly change the subject and admonish: “Och, you’re showing off now.”Donald Clark was born on  July , in Rotten Row hospital, Glasgow. He was the youngest child of Donald Clark and Elizabeth Inglis, following by nine years his only sibling, Fiona.His early years were spent in Inveraray where family le revolved around his parents’ hotel in the little white-washed town.He was schooled at Inveraray Primary and Larchfield in Helensburgh, then Strathallan from  to  where he acquired his love of sports. Contrary to what his dimensions in later le would suggest, he was athletic when young, excelling at rugby and playing for his school and West of Scotland First XV and the old boys’ As.Donald also enjoyed curling, motor boating, snow skiing and water-skiing, where his party piece was to mono-ski down Loch Fyne while drinking a pint of beer.Although not a shinty player, he used his sports experience to coach the Inveraray team in the s and like his father chaired the club. In , he flamboyantly arrived in Inverness by helicopter for Inveraray#s Camanachd Final against Kingussie.

title: nature makes swift return to argyll
story: Susan WindramUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsBefore coronavirus restrictions were imposed, Argyll Bird Club provided monthly field trip outings around mainland Argyll led by experienced bird watchers.With most bird surveying suspended as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, the club is relieved it has now chosen a species which can be surveyed from home within government advice.Swts are slightly larger than swallows and have an all-dark plumage with a short forked tail. They feed on flying insects and spend most of their le in the air # including when they sleep # usually coming down to earth to breed. They are fast fliers, often chasing one another over buildings when they give a screeching call.Swts arrive back in Argyll in early May and breed in towns, villages and other buildings in Argyll. They spend around three months in Argyll, departing early-mid August to their wintering grounds in Africa.The British Trust for Ornithology’s Breeding Bird Survey indicates the population of Swts in Scotland has declined by around  per cent since . A similar decline has taken place in England and Wales. The reasons for the decline are not fully known but are believed to be related to changes in insect numbers and a lack of nesting sites as buildings are modernised.Argyll is at the north-western limit of the world range of Swts. Their distribution and numbers in Argyll is not well-known and the purpose of the Argyll Bird Club Survey is to try to find out the size of the breeding population and where they remain.If you have a Swt nesting in your building, or near you, or would like to take part in this survey further information is available at http:argyllbirdclub.org argyll-surveysFor more information about Argyll Bird Club, email Jim Dickson at Argyllbirder@outlook.

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,A few weeks ago I launched an appeal on social media aimed at supporting nurses and medics at the Mid Argyll Hospital during this terrible COVID- pandemic.I was initially trying to find outthere was anyone locally who might be interested in dusting down their sewing machine to make a few sets of protective ‘scrubs’ to donate to the hospital. Within a couple of days the response was staggering.There were volunteers from all corners of Mid Argyll willing to sew, donate material and give freely of their time. Local businesses were also quick to respond with offers of material, pattern printing and transport for moving stock around.I am overwhelmed by the support and generosity of people in Mid Argyll. They have risen to the challenge and far exceeded my expectations.We have around  stitchers from Cairndow to Ardfern, and villages and towns in between, producing brightly coloured ‘scrubs’ using mainly donated fabric, scrap material and jazzy duvet covers. The first donation of ‘scrubs’ is expected to be handed over to the hospital this week and we are sure they will brighten up the wards.Our crowdfunding page, ‘Let’s Get Scrubbing for Mid Argyll’, was originally set up to buy everything to make the scrubs. It has broken the original £ target and we would love to hit the £, mark so please feel free to donate.I am overwhelmed and humbled by this experience and publicly thank the group team leaders, the volunteer stitchers, those working behind the scenes and the wider community for their support and generosity.My thanks is also extended to the following businesses who have helped in so many ways: MacLeod Construction, Kit-You-Out, Mary’s Meals, Top Designer, West Coast Motors, LG Upholstery, Clock Tower, Tarbert COS Thrt Shop, Premier Laundry, Ian Y McIntyre, Willie Leitch Sailmaker, Owen Sails and the Lithgow Family at Ormsary Estate.Nikki Thompson, Ardrishaig.Sir,The time will come when we are through the turmoil of this pandemic but as we work our way through it, I wanted to share a situation that reflects the actions of many.I was recently collecting shopping in Tarbert for registered vulnerable people and, as I was taking off my gloves before getting into the car, I was aware of another#s presence close by pushing a mobile rubbish bin. It was Damon. He saw me about to put my gloves into the rubbish bag in my own car and said cheerily #You can pop them into this bin here,you like#.I was so taken by that gesture. What an example of initiative, thoughtfulness and kindness. It summed up the incredible work of so many volunteers, co-ordinated by Team Tarbert#s Fiona, with Margaret co-ordinating prescriptions, and many others.Perhaps there is no better time for us all to reaquaint ourselves with Rudyard Kipling#s poem #If#.It seems to perfectly summarise humanity working at its best, in which, during this crisis, thanks to so many, Tarbert can walk tall. Stay safe.Peter Minshall, Tarbert.Sir,I write regarding the Argyllshire Advertiser edition dated Friday April  and the front page heading #Hospital prepares for Pandemic#.The article states: #No figures have been released about the incidence of coronavirus in Argyll and Bute# because the HSCP spokesperson said #we are following national guidance and due to reasons of patient confidentiality we will not be able to make public where in the Highland health board areas the positive cases are#.This statement is complete nonsense and shows either the HSCP in Argyll has not been privy to this information or they are just using the term #national guidance# as a smokescreen and an excuse and or sheer incompetence.No-one was asking them for patients# names and addresses, merely figures of those affected in a given area.The people appointed to positions of responsibility in Argyll and Bute HSCP are hopeless when it comes to joined-up thinking and accountability.All they will do is spin you a line and quote stuff like #national guidelines#, which is code for #I don#t have a clue#.Karl Edwards, LochgilpheadSir,Scottish and Southern Electricity Networksis extending the support it provides to those most vulnerable by expanding the eligibility of its Priority Services Registerto include customers at increased risk of severe illness during the coronavirus pandemic.Nearly , customers already receive additional care and support through SSEN’s PSR – a free, tailored service.In addition to those self-isolating or shielding for  weeks, customers are eligiblethey:Julie Walker, SSEN.

your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsA woman from Minard has been left disappointed after a supermarket failed to deliver on its promise to deliver a special lockdown food package.On its website, Aldi says of its food parcel: #We’ll deliver it straight to your door with full contactless delivery for self-isolators.#As an asthma sufferer self-isolating, Minard resident Tracey Ferguson thought this was a great idea to take the pressure off she and her partner, a key worker in forestry doing -hour shts.Tracey placed the online order on Friday April  for the £. box, containing essentials including handwash, toilet paper, chocolate, UHT milk, part-baked rolls, canned goods, rice, pasta, sauces, tea coffee and biscuits.It was supposed to be delivered by April , but didn#t turn up so Tracey checked the courier website, which advised it was unable to deliver the package, adding #You must take action#.Tracey repeatedly tried to contact Aldi customer services by phone and email.#After several attempts they picked up the phone once, but put me on hold then disappeared,# said Tracey.She was eventually told her money would not be refunded until the package was ed by the courier.Tracey told them the courier hadn#t tried to deliver in the first place.Shortly after the Argyllshire Advertiser contacted Aldi for comment, on May  and after weeks of frustration Tracey received a full refund, a £ online voucher as a #goodwill gesture# and an apology.Later, in an official response, an Aldi spokesperson said: #We apologise that the service Ms Ferguson received fell short of our usual high standards.#We have spoken to her to organise a full refund and will raise this with our delivery partner.#Tracey concluded: #I know it#s not a good time and everyone#s under pressure, but I worked in customer services for  years and you just don#t treat customers like this. title: schools could reopen by august

title: gamers-enjoy-e-sports-success-gala-fairydean-rovers
story: A TEAM of online gamers are representing Gala Fairydean Rovers FC in a virtual football competition.Gas engineer Darren Smith, of Galashiels, helped launch an -a-side league on FIFA  in which his hometown club has been enjoying considerable success.Smith, , told the Border : ldquoConsidering itrsquos the first season, itrsquos been excellent ndash and so has the reaction wersquove got from people.The Scottish league, played on a PlayStation , contains a number of teams representing official clubs, including Berwick Rangers, Greenock Morton andEast Stirlingshire.But the Galashiels side has been performing admirably, according to Smith ndash who has his sights set on a lofty finish.ldquoWersquove only beaten twice, said Smith, whose side currently sit third. ldquoLast Sunday we got beaten and we got beaten on the first day of the season.He added: ldquoWersquore still to play the second-placed team and wersquore still to play the team at the top.ldquoI thinkwe go unbeaten and they drop a few points, itrsquos there to be done and Irsquod be happy with second place.A total of  players have signed up to Galarsquos virtual squad, with three players from the town itself.As the recruitment drive was mainly carried out through Twitter, Smith was able to procure the services of gamers from across Britain and further afield. title: 100th-staging-agricultural-show-postponed
story: FARMERS will have to wait until next year for the th staging of a Borders agricultural show.Organisers of Yarrow  Ettrick Pastoral Society Show have taken the decision to cancel the  edition.The societys secretary Alison Renwick said the committee "felt duty-bound" to call off the showpiece.She added: ldquoThis yearrsquos show would have been particularly memorable, as committee members had already started working on a number of special projects to commemorate the th staging.ldquoThese plans will, of course, now be carried over to the  event and Irsquom very confident next yearrsquos show will prove every bit as successful as this yearrsquos would have been.Although the first show staged by the Yarrow  Ettrick Pastoral Society took place in September, , the societyrsquos origins stretch back  years prior to that with the formation of the Selkirk Farmer Club .The new societyrsquos formation came after a public meeting was held in the Gordon Arms in May, , to "consider the desirability of forming a society for the purpose of organising an annual show of sheep and cattle".Descendants of farmers present at that inaugural meeting continue to live and work in the Yarrow and Ettrick Valleys, thereby helping to keep alive the traditions and high standards which have become the hallmark of the societyrsquos past  shows.The organisers added: "We would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone involved with Yarrow Show, including all volunteers, sponsors, traders, exhibitors and public, whose support is essential to the future of the show."The society looks forward to welcoming you back next year."

title: borders-college-students-deliver-medicine-vulnerable-folk
story: BORDERS College students are delivering medicine to vulnerable peoplersquos homes during lockdown.A total of  students and staff have given up their time to drop off more than  prescriptions across the region.The colleges work placement co-ordinator Verity Hislop said: "The students are quite happy to do it ndash they enjoy it."The college is working with NHS Borders and Scottish Borders Council to run the scheme, which is being led by Ms Hislop.She said: ldquoAlthough wersquove no direct contact with the iniduals wersquore delivering to, we get a wave or a smile or a thank you from a distance."And we certainly know they are appreciative, from the expression on their face."If we didnrsquot deliver, they wouldnrsquot be able to get their medicines.ldquoThese are iniduals who fall into the vulnerable group ndash theyrsquove been told by the NHS they need to isolate.ldquoThere was a huge demand on pharmacies and a lot of iniduals in ious communities fall into the vulnerable category."We sent out a call to staff and students ndash but only those who are PVGscheme members."All the Borders staff fall under that, and also the health and social care students."Originally, pharmacies notied the NHS Borders Transport Hub about prescriptions that needed to be picked up.But now pharmacies are contacting the Borders College delivery team directly with their requests.ldquoThe Transport Hub emailed me with requests for prescription pick-ups from the pharmacy, said Ms Hislop, ldquoand then I would arrange for volunteers to go to the pharmacies, pick up the prescription and deliver them to the people who needed them.ldquoBut now wersquore getting phone calls directly from the pharmacies, with the increase in demand.She added: ldquoBorders College sees its role as supporting our community and during these unprecedented times there is a desire to contribute and add value by volunteering.ldquoThe college is exceptionally proud and grateful to everyone who is involved. This collaborative mission helps to protect vulnerable groups within the community and potentially saves lives.ldquoA huge thank you to all the volunteers, NHS Borders and NHS Transport Hub.

title: gala-rfc-hails-generosity-fans-1-000-goes-foodbank
story: GALASHIELS rugby players have raised more than pound, for the local foodbank ndash and delivered carloads of supplies.Over two successive weekends, Gala RFC invited supporters to drop off food at the gates of Scott Park.Gala president Ian Dalgleish said: ldquoEveryonersquos generosity was fantastic.The weekend of April - saw nearly pound left by players, committee members, supporters and the general public ndash in addition to bags of groceries.The second weekend of collections, on May , raised pound ndash including a bottle of coins totalling pound from residents at Abbotsford Court.Mr Dalgleish said: ldquo[Captain] Euan Dods and [vice captain] Rex Jeffrey and other volunteers were collecting the food and donations at Scott Park, and then the bags were delivered to St Peterrsquos Church for the foodbank.ldquoThe bottle of coins donated by the folk at Abbotsford Court was pound ndash they donrsquot have a lot of money to give out but when they found out there was pound in the bottle they actually topped it up to pound.Galashiels Foodbank co-ordinator John Tucker said: ldquoWe are really thrilled to have all this local support.ldquoNearly pound, was raised in two weekends, and Herculean amounts of food ndash two carloads of food both weekends ndash so our stocks are right up to where we want them to be, which is wonderful.ldquoIn times of hardship people are thinking of each other. The public have really got their support behind this initiative and they just came along with food and money.ldquoBefore COVID, we were giving out maybe  carrier bags of food a week."At [the viruss peak] about two weeks ago we gave out  ndash a fourfold increase in demand.And the foodbank is not the only local charity to benefit from the generosity of the rugby club players.Gala Menrsquos Shed, whose members are making face visors for care workers, was the grateful recipient of a pound donation by the rugby club.Scottish Borders Menrsquos Shed developer Ross Hall described the donation as "fantastic".He said: "It took us over a wee setback in terms of supply, and Gala stepped in at just the right time to help us make more visors."So we had a wee break due to funding and now wersquore back on track. Fantastic news."

title: aussie-rugby-player-caring-galashiels-lockdown
story: A KIND-HEARTED Australian rugby player has been delivering food to elderly folk in the Borders town he currently calls home.Gala RFC forward Cody Roman, , moved from Wollongong, New South Wales, in October last year.When coronavirus put paid to his plans to explore more of the Borders, he decided to channel his free time into volunteering as a driver with Food Train.He said: ldquoIrsquom fortunate that Irsquom mobile so I want to get out and help those who are less fortunate or in need."For six weeks, Cody has been dropping off food to residents who are self-isolating.He said: ldquoIt got to the end of winter and I was looking forward to seeing some nice summer days, and then this [lockdown] happened.ldquoThe club put a post on social media askingthere were any guys ready to help out with anything, like shopping or dog-walking or anything that people were unable to do now, for people who had to self-isolate.ldquoThe Food Train commented on the post, and I was like, lsquoIrsquoll do itrsquo. And Irsquove being doing it for six weeks now.ldquoItrsquos been really good ndash everyone appreciates it. Some people who live alone might not have seen anyone for a few days, so theyrsquore very happy when we come out to them and have a chat.ldquoSome of them are very excited and grateful. Some of them offer us a cup of tea and we have to let them down easy."Despite being so far from his home Down Under, Cody is coping well with the coronavirus lockdown.ldquoItrsquos not too bad, with Facebook and social media and stuff. I can just send messages and give people a call."And Irsquom pretty fortunate where I live ndash everyonersquos very friendly.

title: ex-lauder-footballer-toasts-50th-anniversary-cup-win
story: A REUNION to mark the th anniversary of Lauder Amateur FC clinching the South of Scotland Cup has been cancelled due to coronavirus.Lauder triumphed - over Tweeddale Rovers at Netherdale, Galashiels, on May , .Members of the successful side had been planning to meet up this summer, but COVID- has put paid to the proposal.George Threadgall, , told the Border that he still treasures memories of Lauderrsquos achievement.ldquoIt was like the European Cup for us, said the former defender, adding: ldquoI think half of Lauder was there that night.Led by coaches Jim Brotherston and Alex McDonald, Lauder went down - through an own goal, recalled Mr Threadgall, before roaring back to put their noses in front.After Rovers hoofed a penalty kick over the bar in the dying minutes, Mr Threadgall and team-mates celebrated a famous victory when they arrived home.ldquoYou go to Lauder and mention the South team and locals will bore you to tears about how big a thing it was for the town, said Mr Threadgall, a retired engineer living in Linlithgow.Lauderrsquos goals came courtesy of forwards Jimmy Gillie and Stan Seaton, said Mr Threadgall, with centre-half Kenny Rutherford being the unfortunate player who turned the ball into his own net.The reunion had been planned for late July or early August in Lauderrsquos Golden Bannock pub, said Mr Threadgall.Guests would have included Dave Elrick, now living in South Africa, who was Lauder Cornet in the year he helped his hometown side to the cup.Mr Threadgall, a grandfather, was himself Lauder Cornet in .

title: uk-government-refuses-share-galashiels-virus-results
story: THE UK Government has refused to sendstatistics to the Border relating to coronavirus tests carried out in Galashiels this month.The army ran a temporary testing facilityfor self-isolating key workers and their relatives at the Netherdale car park in the first week of May.But a UK Government spokesperson told this newspaper that the number of people seen at ldquoinidual test sites would not be disclosed.A follow-up request for further details on the Netherdale centre was also turned down this week.Details included whether an extension had been granted.The pop-up facility was one of dozens set up earlier this month as part of the UK Governments push for more testing. The Borders centre was scheduled to run between May  and May .Self-isolating key workers with symptoms were eligible for tests, as were their relatives living under the same roof.These are the questions which the Border posed to the UK Government on May :How many people have visited the Galashiels testing centre so far How many of those have received a positive diagnosis for the virus How do the number of visitors to the site in Galashiels compare to those in other mobile centres established in Scotland How do the number of positive cases confirmed at the Galashiels site compare to other centres in Scotland What further advice treatment is offered to those who test positive at a drive through centre Will the government extend theof time the town has this mobile testing facility beyond May  As the sites are only open to those showing signs of the virus or who are living with someone with symptoms, what is the purpose of these tests

title: furlough-extended-october-questions-answered
story: Chancellor Rishi Sunak has saidthe UK Governmentrsquos furlough scheme willbe extended until the end of October.But what does it all mean for workers and businesses Heres what you need to know.What will happen to workers on furlough Mr Sunak said they will continue to receive  per centof their pay ndash up to pound, a month ndash until the end of October.This extends the original furlough scheme to eight months since it was launched in March.The Chancellor also said there will be the possibility of part-time s for staff from August, pointing out that manufacturers have been asking for staggered shts to reopen production lines.Are there more details on part-time s and can I take a job where The details will be published later this month, but Mr Sunak stressed to MPs that furloughed workers can take jobs where while on the scheme.Government advice says: ldquoIf your contract allows, you may undertake other employment while your current employer has placed you on furlough, and this will not affect the grant that they can claim under the scheme.However, staff cannot work for their employer while furloughed.Will the Government continue covering the cost The Government will fund the furlough scheme, which has supported seven million jobs at a cost of pound billion a month, until the end of July.After that, companies will be expected to make a contribution to the payments, although the amount workers take home will not fall below the  per cent mark.How much will businesses be expected to pay towards furlough The details will be published later this month, the Chancellor said, but it is likely to be judged on a sector-by-sector basis, similar to the details published on Monday by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategyfor companies looking to reopen under new ldquoCovid Secure measures.With certain sectors ing to some normality, others, including restaurants and gyms, remain unlikely to reopen fully for several months.Can we expect to see furlough extended beyond October The Government has said it will continue to monitor the situation and is willing to adjust advice accordingly.But Mr Sunak made clear it is unlikely to be extended.He told the Commons: ldquoWe will keep everything under review but my expectation is by thenthe scheme should end. Wersquove stretched and strained to be as generous as possible to businesses and workers, which is why we have made the decision that wersquove made today.The Chancellor added: ldquoBut hellip this scheme is expensive. Itrsquos the right thing to do. The cost of not acting would have been far higher but itrsquos not something that can continue indefinitely into the future. Eight months of total support is a considerable amount of time.Are there any other signicant changes to the furlough scheme More details will come this month, but MPs raised concerns from self-employed workers who pay themselves via idends, asking whether they would be able to receive further support.However, Mr Sunak insisted current support is strong enough.Why is the Government announcing the extension now Under employment laws, companies must start informing any staff they plan to make redundant within  days of any changes.The previous furlough scheme was due to end by July, meaning consultations would need to begin imminently, but the extension to October will address it.

title: borders-actor-jack-lowden-narrates-bbc-football-documentary

title: let-borders-garden-centres-open-soon-says-msp
story: BORDERS residents should be allowed to visit garden centres soon, according to a politician.Christine Grahame MSP has asked the Scottish Government to consider re-opening such businesses with safety measures in place.Ms Grahame, of the SNP, highlighted the "physical and mental wellbeing benefits" of gardening.The member for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale addressed Holyroods rural economy and connectivity committee this morning.She said: ldquoAny re-opening of businesses of course needs to be done in a safe manner, giving proper consideration to the safety of both staff and the public."Irsquom optimistic that this may be possible with garden centres soon, given the physical and mental wellbeing benefits gardening can offer for us all in lockdown.ldquoIf yoursquore fortunate enough to have access to a garden it can make a real dference and being able to buy some supplies for it could be a real boost to many. Indeed even a window box can make a dference. While you can currently buy online, it is not as satisfactory.ldquoOur horticultural sector has been hit hard by lockdown, with many businesses losing out on what would be one of their busiest periods of trade in spring and early summer."This not only affects the big well known chains, but smaller local businesses and growers.ldquoI welcome news that this is being given serious consideration and I trust the Scottish Government will authorise re-opening soon."

title: john-lamont-cancels-summer-tour-first-time-14-years
story: A BORDERS politician has announced he is cancelling his summer surgery tour for the first time in more than a decade.John Lamont MP and Rachael Hamilton MSP, both Conservatives, had been due to visit  towns and villages over the summer.But with coronavirus restrictions in place, the pair are scrapping their plans.Mr Lamont, who formerly held Ms Hamiltons Holyrood seat, expressed sadness that he would be missing an annual "highlight" for himself.He said: "Irsquom really disappointed that for the first time in  years, it will not be happening this summer."The member for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk ndash who won his first parliamentary election in  ndash said it is important to follow government advice aimed at limiting the spread of COVID-.He added that he continues to hold surgeries over the phone.Ms Hamilton, who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire in the Scottish Parliament, said she is also "disappointed" about the tour cancellation.She added: "I am very much looking forward to meeting constituents again in hopefully the near future when the restrictions are safely lted."

title: borders-businessman-making-living-unwanted-trees
story: AN ENTREPRENEUR is enjoying success by helping to make houses, animal shavings and food pallets.Douglas Mathison, , of Peeblesshire, fells trees across the south of Scotland through his company Agrorest.ldquoEven with the poorest quality timber, you can still get a lot of use out of it, says Mr Mathison, explaining that unwanted woods on farms and estates have the potential to serve a iety of purposes.Once the timber has been taken to the sawmill, Mr Mathison says, the best of it gets transformed into timber-framed houses, while the scraps might ultimately line a rabbit hutch.When Agrorest was founded in , it served a role that was ldquounique in the south of Scotland, according to Mr Mathison.Established firms often shunned the type of tasks that Agrorest expressed an interest in, he says.ldquoWhen I first started, we were the only one in the south of Scotland that was doing this work on a very small basis, Mr Mathison says.ldquoWersquove been taking on an increasing workload, focusing on smaller jobs that other companies are not interested in working on.Although there are now three or four other firms carrying out a similar role in the region, according to Mr Mathison, Agrorest continues to field enquiries from Kilmarnock to West Linton and beyond.Explaining the typical process, Mr Mathison says an initial phone call will often lead to a site visit, which in turn results in Mr Mathison estimating the potential financialthat could be made on a patch of woodlandfelled.If the farmer wishes to press ahead and Mr Mathison secures a licence from Scottish Forestry, Agrorest will send in the machinery, remove the trees and take the timber to sawmills.The farmer can be paid within a few weeks, according to Mr Mathison, who shares a portion of the money he receives from the mills.Aside from felling, Agrorest carries out replanting and also manages a number of estates.Mr Mathison says his success has overcome a historical perception among certain landowners that woodland is ldquonot worth bothering about.In his experience, he says, an undermanaged patch of trees will be worthy of attention ldquonine times out of .Mr Mathison is a former Peebles High School pupil who went on to study rural business management in Edinburgh.He launched Agrorest after a stint working for a large timber harvesting company.

title: golfers-raise-10-000-peebles-golf-club
story: GOLFERS have donated more than pound, to help Peebles Golf Club while the course is closed.The clubs fundraising drive, launched after the coronavirus lockdown, collected more than pound, last month.Les Biscomb, of the clubs sponsorship sub-committee, hailed the generosity of donors.Reflecting on the campaign so far, he said: ldquoItrsquos been a tremendous success."Unlike golf clubs south of the border, Scottish courses remain closed ndash meaning clubhouse coffers continue to struggle.But the idea of setting up a fundraiser in Peebles has already been vindicated, according to Mr Biscomb.He said: "As a team, we came up with the idea of, while wersquore in lockdown, our members might have vastly reduced income ndash theyrsquore being paid to work at home or are pensioners ndash but therersquos nowhere to spend your money at the moment."You canrsquot go to golf, you canrsquot go down the pub, you canrsquot go to restaurants, many people arenrsquot driving anywhere, so we thought, while wersquore in lockdown, why donrsquot we ask the members in Peebles, who are kindhearted and generous, to put something each month towards a crowdfunder.Comments by donors on the website include, Have my coffee money for the coming month otherwise Irsquoll probably fritter it away and Glad to donate again to ensure our club survives.The sub-committee originally set a target of pound, each month, but received more than pound, in April.Mr Biscomb said: ldquoWe would have been delightedwersquod raised the pound, but in the very first month alone we got to pound,."Some of those were one-offs, so people just wanted to join in with the giving and the spirit of helping the club but even so,you look at May, wersquore already at pound,.ldquoWe were hoping for this to continue for two or three months, pound, a month, just to add in the coffers."This isnrsquot funding thatrsquos needed immediately ndash from a cash perspective, Peebles is doing well."This is really for the quiet periods. Once we turn the corner into next year, thatrsquos really when we might need this money, in the quieter days.ldquoBut who knows whatrsquos going to happen with lockdown, and when wersquore going to get cash back through other means, like the bar and catering, and visitors.Currently, all club staff are on furlough, with the exception of head greenkeeper Steve Borthwick.ldquoSteversquos going a fantastic job, said Mr Biscomb. "The course is in magnicent condition ndash it is very tempting to get out there.Meanwhile, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has announced that golf clubs in England can re-open, as long as social distancing guidelines are followed.Mr Biscomb conceded he is "quite jealous", but indicated he is satisfied with the Scottish rules.He said: ldquoIrsquod love to get out on the golf course. But equally, we understand that the Scottish Government is not ready because the stats are not there."Theyrsquore not comfortable with opening golf clubs and we have to respect that."Hopefully, in a few weeksrsquo time,the number [of virus cases] comes down, we can start to get out in ones and twos."For now, we have to live with it and be sensible."Wersquore in the eighth week already ndash another couple of weeks wonrsquot do any harm."Itrsquos achievable to be sensible for another few weeks.Donations to Peebles Golf Club can be made via: www.justgiving crowdfunding pgcmembersappealfund

title: mountain-bikers-told-ride-within-limits-lockdown
story: MOUNTAIN bikers have been issued with guidance during lockdown.Scottish Cyclinghas outlined a series of dos and donts following the Scottish Governments go-ahead for people to exercise more than once a day.There are four rules cyclists and mountain bikers must adhere to under the new SC guidelines:Only ride from your home ndash it is not essential travel to go mountain biking or cycling and you may face enquiries from the policeyou are stopped en route or ing from a ride. All Forestry and Land Scotland car parks and trails, including the stanes sites, remain closedDo not go far ndash whilst you can go exercise for longer, we recommend riding close to where you live and not into remote areas ndash think more smaller loops rather than one longer remote rideRide well within your limits ndash only ride on trails that are that you are very confident you will be able to ride safely and within your competency. It is highly unlikely that mountain rescue are back to full operations ndash consider the fact that a full rescue may not be possible and may take longer to get to youOnly cycle with members of your own household - keep a safe distance when passing other cyclists or pedestrians.Mountain biking trails such as the stanes at Glentress, Peebles, and Innerleithen are closed until further notice to restrict travel to the trails and for safety as they are not being maintained as they were before lockdown.However, walking trails owned by Forestry and Land Scotland are open to members of the public who can access them without using transport.

story: SUBWAY in Galashiels has re-opened for takeaway and delivery.The sandwich store, which had closed due to coronavirus restrictions, welcomed customers back this week.The Channel Street premises opened its doors again on Monday , applying social distancing guidance and using protective gear.Store supervisor Imran Han said the shop has been "busy".

title: borders-lib-dems-select-ettrick-roxburgh-berwickshire-candidate
story: THE Liberal Democrats have selected a candidate for next years Holyrood election.Jenny Marr will stand for the Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire constituency ndash currently held by Conservative Rachael Hamilton.The former Selkirk High pupil said: "Irsquom thrilled to have been chosen to represent Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire for the Scottish Liberal Democrats."We are living in extraordinary times and I have been blown away by how communities across the Borders have rallied to support each other."The most important thing we can do as politicians and political parties is to provide assistance to anyone that needs it, learn from our experiences and work to address inequalities which have manest."The vote is set to take place on Thursday, May  of next year.

title: borders-based-msp-introduces-online-advice-surgeries
story: A BORDERS-BASED MSP is introducing video surgeries for his constituents.Paul Wheelhouse, who represents the South of Scotland, has had to temporarily close his Hawick office due to the coronavirus outbreak.But from next Friday, Borderers will be able to have a face-to-face meeting ndash without leaving their homes.Mr Wheelhouse said: "Video advice surgeries will be secure and confidential. Constituents will be able to talk to me as though we were sitting down together in person."I fully appreciate that many people do not have video-conferencing technology, or do not even have the internet in their home. For those people, my office is still contactable by telephone at this time."The online advice surgeries are to complement, not replace, other forms of communication. I would strongly encourage anyone who needs my support to get in touch, either by email or phone, and myself and my team will assist in any way we can."Mr Wheelhousersquos first online surgery will take place from pm on Friday, May .To make an appointment, email: paul.wheelhouse.msp@parliament.scot

title: 75-students-without-laptop-get-device-borders-college
story: BORDERS College has loaned laptops to  students who did not have regular access to a suitable device at home.With face-to-face classes cancelled due to coronavirus restrictions, learning has been taking place remotely.Student who did not have adequate laptops of their own have been allowed to borrow from the Galashiels campus.Sport and exercise student Harrison Dixon, from Earlston, said he was "delighted" with the scheme.He said: ldquoMy personal computer is old and struggling to work with some of the new applications and online resources that we are now using, so I spoke with my course tutor who made me aware of the loan scheme, and I was delighted when it was delivered last week."Having the laptop will allow me to continue with my studies remotely.The college says it has loaned a total of  laptops, including those allocated through its bursary programme.Head of IT Scott Moncrieff said: ldquoBefore the college closed, we were able to prepare and distribute  laptops to students for use."Since lockdown, we have had an additional  requests, which we have been able to fulfil.ldquoAny students who find themselves in the situation that continuing their education is not possible, because they donrsquot have an appropriate device, should contact their course tutor or achievement coach, and they will make the appropriate arrangements.

title: historic-borders-houses-feature-visitscotland-campaign
story: HISTORIC homes in the Borders are featuring in a social media campaign by VisitScotland.The tourist organisation has launched #AWindowOnScotland, which asks people to take a photo from their window.Traquair House, Peeblesshire, is among the stately homes in the Borders taking part, with views from the th century Aikwood Tower, near Selkirk, also being shared across social media.Gillian Steele, chairwoman of Big Houses in the Scottish Borders, said: "I donrsquot think people will necessarily forget we are here, but with us all looking out of our windows dreaming of that day when we can travel again, and indulge our passion for Scottish heritage, this campaign strikes a chord."VisitScotlandrsquos #AWindowOnScotland campaign provides us with a great visual opportunity to continue to promote our Houses, their gardens and their wildle from the same perspective as everyone at home."Irsquom encouraging all the Big Houses to take part, and I hope between the eleven of us we will give visitors a reminder of how beautul our Houses and gardens look this month."The campaigns hashtag has been used , times, with towns and villages across the Borders taking part.Historic buildings participating include Thirlestane Castle, near Lauder, and Mellerstain House, near Kelso.VisitScotlands regional leadership director Paula Ward said: ldquoWersquore thrilled at the reaction to #AWindowOnScotland from residents across the Scottish Borders and heartened that businesses are engaging with the campaign and using the opportunity to share their windows on Scotland with the world during this challenging time.ldquoThe staycation market will be a key driver in the countryrsquos economic recovery and the many wonderful views people have been sharing while they stay at home will surely be an incentive for many to travel when the time comes.ldquoThe campaign is far from over and wersquod encourage residents and businesses to continue posting their views, however they may look, as it is all Scotland, to help lt the spirits of those at home and abroad.To join the campaign, take a photo of a view from your window and share it online using #AWindowOnScotland, then tag your location.

title: national-express-plans-resume-coach-services-july-1
story: National Express has started selling UK coach tickets as it plans to restart services on July .The tickets will be available for a "core coach network" andwill focus on large and medium-sized towns and cities.Revenue dropped about  per cent in April compared withthe same month last year, National Express revealed, as the Government advised Britons to keep away from public transport.Nevertheless, Ebitdawas positive and slightly ahead of expectations as National Express slashed costs by about pound million.What hasNational Express said In a statement to customers, National Express said: "We have extended the temporary suspension of our coach services."A restricted timetable is currently scheduled to resume from Wednesday, July , ."Please note, however, all services are subject to change depending on Government advice."For thosethat have an upcoming journey booked with us on or before June ,  and would like to amend your booking, you can do so for free, for travel any time in the next  months."There is no need to contact us straight away, just completeour ticket amendment formbefore your original outward journey and get back in touch with us when yoursquore ready to travel again."If you do not wish to amend your ticket to another date, we will provide a full refund. If you havenrsquot already done so, please completeour refund formand we will process your refund within  days."Please stay safe and well and, when the time is right, we look forward to welcoming you back on board."Where does National Express travel to The company runs coach services across the UK, including Manchester to Coventry, London to Worthing, Newcastle via Darlington to London, Liverpool to Leeds, Edinburgh and Glasgow to London, plus Bradford to London.

title: graphic-designer-reveals-inspired-borders-kids
story: A GRAPHIC designer is helping to keep families entertained during lockdown after creating free colouring packs.Kate Pearson, , who owns K Graphic Design, has created six art packs to help ease the boredom of being stuck indoors.Kate, of Peebles, said: "I absolutely love my job because I get to be creative every day."Each pack features dferent activities for children ndash and adults ndash including colouring, design, and games like word searches.Kate said: "Just before lockdown, I spoke to the pupils at my old primary school, Priorsford Primary School, about my career."I left feeling inspired by their enthusiasm and the idea of activity packs was born."She had planned to print the packs but wanted them to be accessible so made them digital ndash a decision which has paid off.The downloads page on her website has been visited more than , times in the last two months, she said.Kate ensured that each pack had something for everyone, with themes including rainbows and dinosaurs."They were designed with young people in mind, but have proved to be just as popular with adults ndash especially the dinosaur one," said Kate.Kate also owns Glass Bulldog Wedding Stationary, and with wedding fairs for  cancelled or postponed, both sides of her business have taken a knock."Ninety per cent of my bookings have been cancelled or postponed until next year ndash many of my suppliers are affected too," said Kate."I really feel for all businesses facing closure and couples postponing their weddings."Like everyone, the biggest challenge of COVID- is not seeing friends and family, but staying at home is such a small price to pay to stay safe ndash especially now lsquoNeighboursrsquo is back on five days a week!"Kate ed to Peebles only a few years ago, after enjoying multiple career roles including as a wedding planner and working for a London-based design agency.Looking to the future, Kate already has three new packs in mind and hopes to eventually print the activity books.She also hopes that once the Borders s to normal, many of her usual services will be back up and running, especially those catered for weddings and events."My clients range from small local start-ups to The Botanic Gardens and Amazon ndash no two days are the same," she said."Going freelance also means I can take my dog, Dr Frankenstein, to work. What more could you ask for "

title: tesco-clubcard-vouchers-set-expire-extended-november-2020
story: A BATCH of Tesco Clubcard vouchershave been extended by the supermarket.The extension comes as Tesco says customers across the UK have not been shopping as frequently as before the lockdown period began in March.Herersquos everything you need to know.Changing shopping habitsWith some customers unable to visit stores at all during lockdown, and others visiting less frequently, shopping habits have changed over the past few months.Tesco has reported that visits to the supermarket have halved since lockdown, but basket sizes have doubled.Clubcard vouchers extendedHowever, those with Clubcard vouchers could now be struggling to spend them before they expire,they cannot get to a store or book a delivery slot.Tesco has therefore issued a statement to shoppers stating that Clubcard points that were due to expire this month will now be extended, Manchester Evening News reports.Zoe Evans, of Tescos customer engagement centre, said:"We appreciate that, for many reasons, most of us arenrsquot shopping as often as we did before lockdown."As a little help from Clubcard, we want to give you more time to use your vouchers which were due to expire on May , ."Any vouchers issued in May  will now not expire until November , , giving you an extra six months to use them."Well update the expiry date on your digital vouchers, and well continue to accept paper vouchers in-store until the extended expiry date. We really hope it helps, and take care."

title: asda-employees-galashiels-start-using-electric-vehicles
story: STAFF at Asda in Galashiels have started using electric vehicles at work.The vehicles are being used to help with the click and collect service.Previously, delivery vans moved items from the store to the click and collect lockers across the car park.But now the task is performed by the electric vehicles, freeing up the vans to carry out more home deliveries.Asda director Emma Ford said: ldquoWe are always looking for ways to innovate in areas where customers care, while still providing an excellent customer experience.ldquoThese vehicles allow us to do this by increasing capacity for click and collect customers and enabling us to understand how we can better utilise electric vehicles across our fleet.The fully road-legal electric vans will allow all UK stores with a click and collect service to increase their slot availability from , to , per week, according to Asda.

title: borders-golfers-allowed-play-says-msp
story: BORDERS golfers and anglers should be allowed toto action, according to Rachael Hamilton.The Conservative MSP says she has written to the Scottish Government in a bid to get restrictions lted on outdoor activities.Mrs Hamilton said shooting and angling are among the activities which make an "immense contribution" to the rural economy.She said: "Outdoor sports, such as golfing, hiking and fishing, could take place with the necessary social distancing measures and it would not jeopardise the governmentrsquos efforts in tackling this pandemic."Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced last week that residents in England canto certain outdoor pursuits, including tennis and golf.But the Scottish Government has decided to retain the stay at home message, while now allowing people to exercise more than once a day.Mrs Hamilton, who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, says she has written to the Scottish cabinet secretary for rural economy and tourism, Fergus EwingMrs Hamilton, the shadow secretary, said: "We currently have an extraordinary situation in my constituency, around Coldstream, where people can happily fish in the English half of the River Tweed, whilst anglers in Scotland can only watch on from the Scottish side, where fishing is still not permitted at this time."By their nature, outdoor-based sports see participants spread out, whether over a hillside, across an open space or along a river."In the Borders and across rural Scotland, the angling and shooting industry needs to have clarity so it can plan for the new season."I urge the Scottish Government to rethink its restrictions, given the nature of these sports, and the immense contribution they make to our rural economy."

title: international-space-station-see-uk-live
story: DETAILS of how and when to spot the International Space Station above the UK at night have been revealed.The stationflies above our heads constantly, and orbits the planet every  minutes at a height of over  miles.Of course, its impossible to see during the day, but at night - and with the space stations orbit passing over Britain just so - it takes on the appearance of a bright star moving across the sky.It can actually be startling when you first spot it - a glowing orb without the telltale flashes of an aircrafts wing drting silently through the dark - but the station passes overhead fairly frequently.It goes through periods when we wont be able to see it for months, as its diagonal orbit crosses other parts of the planet, but every now and then, there comes a space of a few weeks when it flies overhead - and at night.Times y ever so slightly depending on your location, but weve used those given by NASAs Spot the Station website for Lancaster - the closest point we could find to the geographical centre of the UK - to try to give a good average.Here are the dates and times of when the station will become visible, with details ofhow long it will be in the sky in brackets. Heres when to see it:May  - .am May  - :am May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :am May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :pm May  - :pm May  - :am May  - :pm May  - :pm May  - :pm For more information, and for timings more specic to where you live, visit NASAs Spot the Station website- spotthestation.nasa.gov.How do I see it You should have no trouble spotting the International Space Station as it drts overhead - we say drt, but its actually travelling at more than , mph.The station takes on the appearance of a bright star, and is usually much brighter than anything  in the sky.Sometimes the station will rise over the horizon other times it might fade into view in the middle of the night sky as it enters into the suns light.It will always appear in the west, and will travel eastwards.,params: .pushAnd just as it appears, it may disappear in the same way, growing fainter and fainter until its completely enshrouded by the Earths shadow.Youll easily be able to spot it with the naked eye , though even modestly priced binoculars may be able to pick out some of the stations details, like its large solar .So take a look up, theres a good chance youll spot the International Space Station, and it can be amazing to think there are actually people living up there and conducting experiments within the space environment.The experiments that they carry out would be almost impossible to replicate on earth.

title: colouring-packs-given-borders-sheltered-housing-residents
story: STAFF at sheltered housing in Innerleithen have gted activity packs to residents.Tenants of Mercer Court, in the townrsquos Angle Park, have been relieved of lockdown boredom after the generosity of Hanover Scotland employees.Items given to residents include word searches, crosswords, colouring-in packs, pens and pencils.Mercer Court development manager Kathleen Ewart said the response has been "grand", adding: "On the whole, itrsquos gone down well.Some of the kit was bought by staff, while other pieces were donated by the owner of the Treasure Island gt shop, Martha Gibson.Ms Ewart said: ldquoThe residents were getting a bit fed up, the longer lockdown was going on, so I thought it was time to find something to help pass the time.ldquoSome of our tenants have been able to get out for walks but some are shielding, some have health issues that mean it wouldnrsquot be appropriate for them to go out, some of them are of an age where they want to stay in even though theyrsquore mobile ndash theyrsquore a bit scared to go out.ldquoI knew that some of them liked doing things like crosswords and word searches, some people like colouring in, so we put things like that in the pack.ldquoI bought the activities but didnrsquot have enough colouring pens, so contacted Martha at Treasure Island to seeshe had any in her shop and she gave us a lot for free.Ms Ewart added: ldquoThe colouring in has gone down really well, and some of them have coloured the pictures in and given them back, so Irsquove laminated them and put them up."

title: nicola-sturgeon-lockdown-restrictions-eased-may-28---know
story: DETAILS of how Scotland will ease lockdown restrictions will be published laterthis week.The First Minister today revealed that the Scottish Government will publish a route map for the paths out of lockdown.She said thatprogress is being made in reducing the spread of the virus, changes could be made after the next review date of May .This would come after taking into account the reproduction rateof the virus, alongside the findings of the weekly National Records of Scotlandreport.Ms Sturgeon said changes could include some sporting events being allowed, including golf and fishing, as well as the opening of garden centres.Other potential easings includeletting people meet those from other households, provided social distancing is followed.The First Minister also said that more will be said about when schools might reopen.The First Minister said at the briefing: ldquoWithin two weeks, my hope is that we will be taking some concrete steps on the journey back to normality.ldquoAs Irsquove said before, it wonrsquot be normality as we knew it because the virus will not have gone away, but it will be a journey to a better balance ndash I hope ndash than the one we have today.ldquoAs we take each step, we must make sure that the ground beneath us is as solid as possible.ldquoThatrsquos why sticking with the lockdown restrictions a bit longer to suppress the virus more is so important, because that will mean we can start to take these steps with the confidence that we have alternative means of effectively keeping it under control.The First Minister said for the moment there is no change to the lockdown advice currently being circulated by the Scottish Government.

title: coronavirus-scotland-many-cases-live
story: The latest coronavirus figures for Scotland have been released.Earlier, speaking at the latest Scottish Government coronavirus briefing in Edinburgh, the First Ministerrevealed patients have died in Scotland after testing positive for coronavirus, up two from  on Sunday.She issued a note of caution over the death figures, saying although these can be registered at the weekend, registrations tend to be lower.Nicola Sturgeonsaid there are  patients in hospital with confirmed or suspected Covid-, up  from  on Sunday.Of these,  are in intensive care, a rise of four.Now, a breakdown of the figures hasbeen released for each health board.Greater Glasgow and Clyde remains the health board in Scotland with the most cases.There,  people are confirmed to have had the virus to date - with  confirmedcases in hospital and  in intensive care.In NHS Lothian, there are  cases.There,  people are in hospital with confirmed coronavirus, with half the number of Glasgows intensive care cases.On the westcoast, Ayrshire is nearing  confirmed cases, currently sitting at  - with  people in hospital and five in intensive care.And in the Borders,  people have had the virus to date.They have  people in hospital, with less than five people in intensive care.

title: borders-mp-reveals-rejected-bid-help-farmers
story: A BORDERS politician has defended himself after rejecting an opportunity to ban imports of low quality meat.John Lamont MP was among the Westminster parliamentarians who turned down an attempt to protect food standards last week.But Mr Lamont, of the Conservatives, says the UK Government will ensure British farmers are not hurt by future trade deals.He said: ldquoCritically, we will maintain our import standards, which include the ban on chlorine-washed chicken and hormone-injected beef.Some farming figures criticised politicians for failing to back Neil Parish MPrsquos amendment to the Agriculture Bill in the House of Commons on May .Mr Parish said the amendment aimed to make sure food imports are produced to the equivalent standards upheld in the UK.NFU Scotlandrsquos director of policy Jonnie Hall said it was ldquodeeply disappointing that the amendment lost by  votes.Mr Lamont told the Border he was ldquounable to support all of the amendments.The member for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk added: ldquoThe government has made it clear that no UK import standards will be diminished as part of any free trade agreement.ldquoWe will also not undermine our high domestic environmental protection, animal welfare and food safety standards by ensuring in any agreement British farmers are always able to compete.ldquoI know that the UK Government is working very closely with industry figures to get the best trade deal that will allow Scottish farming to flourish.The Agriculture Bill passed its third reading in the House of Commons and will now be considered by the House of Lords.

title: happened-councils-first-virtual-meeting
story: TODAYsaw an unusual, yet historic, occasion for Scottish Borders Councilas it held its first virtual committee meeting since lockdown began.A total of nine councillors participated in the meeting of the planning and building standardscommittee, which gave approval for a houseto be built in Newstead.Chairman Tom Miers, a Conservative representative for Leaderdale and Melrose, said the meeting "went well given the circumstances".Journalists were allowed to view proceedings, conducted through Microsoft Teams, after the council made a U-turn on its original decision to ban the press.Mr Miers said: "Its not as good as meeting face to face. I would prefer to be able to have public input into the meetings, which is hard to do remotely."Also, it may be harder to have detailed technical discussion on matters of process in this medium at future meetings."Wersquoll see, and wersquoll adapt as necessary to make it as good as possible."We were able to conduct a full discussion of the issues and we heard a range of views from dferent councillors. So the PBS committee fulfilled its remit properly."Dreaded technical dficulties reared their head on several occasions, however ndash some councillors struggled with muting and un-muting their microphones.After they backed an application to build a house, Mr Miers reminded elected members that feedback was welcome on how the meeting went.As affairs drew to a close, conversation turned to facial hair grown since the last face-to-face meeting on March .One officer said his new beard "wont be lasting long".JS Crawford Farming Partnership has won permission to build a property on the corner of Main Street and Eddy Road.

title: borders-pupils-achieve-first-ever-higher-enterprise
story: BORDERS students are among the first in the country to gain a Higher in enterprise.Six pupils from Earlston High School completed Young Enterprise Scotlands Company Programme, despite the challenges posed by lockdown.Chloe Harper said: "I have gained confidence and communication skills that I did not have before."The Level  qualication is the equivalent of a Higher.The six Earlston students worked on the GR project, which provided "succulent plants potted in recycled glass jars and decorated for the season."GR was originally made up of seven students, but one chose not to complete the extra two units required for the Higher qualication.The programme, also taught at Berwickshire High School, asked the young people to create their own brand and develop a product.But they also had to show knowledge of the financial and marketing aspects of running a business.Despite lockdown limiting students access to their usual resources, they were able to speak with their tutors and advisers to achieve their results.YES chief executive Geoff Leask congratulated everyone who took part.He said: "This is the first year that students participating in our Company Programme could achieve a lsquoHigherrsquo equivalent qualication and credit points for their hard work and I applaud everyone who took part."As it turned out, they could not have faced a more challenging set of circumstances and yet their commitment and resilience during the coronavirus lockdown has paid off."These students can justiably call themselves leaders as the first to hold the new qualication."Two other programme teams from Earlston High completed their tasks successfully.Housweet made "luxury gingerbread houses", while Custom Acrylic designed "bespoke acrylic block signs made in the Scottish Borders".Hannah Hutchison from Housweet said: "YES has been challenging and taught me about perseverance, team-working and time management."And Custom Acrylics Lewis Anderson added: "YES has been challenging but has taught us how to work as a team, build our confidence to speak publicly and work through any challenges we faced."The YES Company Programme was taught at  schools in  regions in Scotland, with a total of  students gaining the Level  qualication.

title: launches-investigation-handling-pandemic
story: The World Health Organisationhas bowed to calls from most of its member states to launch an independent investigation into its management of the international response to the coronavirus.The move comes after weeks of finger-pointing between the US and China over the pandemic, which has killed more than , people and devastated the global economy.The ldquocomprehensive evaluation, sought by a coalition of African, European and other countries, is intended to review ldquolessons learned from WHOrsquos coordination of the global response to Covid-.But it would stop short of examining contentious issues such as the origins of the new coronavirus.US President Donald Trump has claimed he has proof suggesting the coronavirus originated in a lab in China, while the scientic community has insisted all evidence to date shows the virus likely jumped into humans from animals.In Washington on Monday, Mr Trump criticised the WHO for having done ldquoa very sad job and said he was considering whether to cut the annual US funding of the body from  milliona year to  million .ldquoThey gave us a lot of bad advice, terrible advice, he said. ldquoThey were wrong so much, always on the side of China.Later on Monday, Mr Trump tweeted a letter he had sent WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus in which the president said ldquothe only way forward wasWHO ldquocan actually demonstrate independence from China.Mr Trump said unless WHO committed to ldquosubstantive improvements over the next  days he would make his temporary suspension of US funding permanent.to obtain the information that the world needed and that failure cost many lives" data-source"US Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar"WHOrsquos normally bureaucratic annual assembly this week has been overshadowed by mutual recriminations and political sniping between the US and China.Mr Trump has repeatedly attacked WHO, claiming it helped China conceal the extent of the coronavirus pandemic in its early stages. Several Republican politicians have called on Dr Tedros to resign.US Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar said on Monday it was time to be frank about why Covid- has ldquospun out of control.ldquoThere was a failure by this organisation to obtain the information that the world needed and that failure cost many lives, Mr Azar said.Speaking hours after Chinese President Xi Jinping announced China would provide  billionto help respond to the outbreak and its economic fallout, Mr Azar said the US had allocated  billionto coronavirus containment efforts around the world.Dr Tedros said he would launch an independent evaluation of WHOrsquos response ldquoat the earliest appropriate moment mdash alluding to findings published on Monday in a first report by an oversight advisory body commissioned to look into WHOrsquos response.vw,vw,px, px"President Donald Trump has been pointing the finger at the WHO and at China The -page report raised questions such as whether WHOrsquos warning system for alerting the world to outbreaks is adequate, and suggested member states might need to ldquoreassess WHOrsquos role in providing travel advice to countries.In his opening remarks at the WHO meeting, Dr Tedros held firm and sought to focus on the bigger troubles posed by the outbreak, saying ldquowe have been humbled by this very small microbe.ldquoThis contagion exposes the fault lines, inequalities, injustices and contradictions of our modern world, Dr Tedros said. ldquoAnd geopolitical isions have been thrown into sharp relief.China, meanwhile, sought to ert attention to its renewed efforts to slow the coronavirus pandemic, with Mr Xi announcing the  billion outlay over two years to fight it. Last year, China donated some  millionto the WHO.US National Security Council spokesman John Ullyot characterised Chinarsquos newly announced contribution as ldquoa token to distract from calls from a growing number of nations demanding accountability for the Chinese governmentrsquos failure to meet its obligations.He said since China was ldquothe source of the outbreak, it had ldquoa special responsibility to pay more and give more.vw,vw,px, px"President Xi Jinping insists China has acted openly and honestly over the coronavirus outbreak Mr Xi insisted China had acted with ldquoopenness, transparency and responsibility when the epidemic was detected in Wuhan.He said China had give all relevant outbreak data to WHO and other countries, including the virusrsquos genetic sequence, ldquoin a most timely fashion.Mr Xi said that in recent weeks China had dispatched medical supplies to more than  African countries and that  Chinese medical teams were currently on the continent helping local officials.Other world leaders including the presidents of France, South Korea and South Africa and Germanyrsquos chancellor were also piped in to throw their support to the WHO, which has been put on the defensive from a Trump administration that has blamed it for mishandling the outbreak and showering excessive praise on Chinarsquos response.The European Union and others staked out a middle ground.Mr Xi has said China supports the idea of a comprehensive review of the global response to Covid- and that it should be ldquobased on science and professionalism led by WHO, and conducted in an objective and impartial manner..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: WHO launches investigation of its handling of pandemic

title: 2-600-jobs-go-energy-supplier-ovo-buys-sse
story: More than , employees of energy supplier SSE are set to lose their jobs as new owner Ovo announced sweeping redundancies across its business.Ovo will ask its staff to apply for voluntary redundancy as it tries to shed , roles after the coronavirus crisis forced it to speed up integration plans, it said on Tuesday.Around eight in  of these will be among the workers who came to Ovo as part of its pound million deal to buy SSErsquos retail arm.The lionrsquos share of the lost jobs will be among those who work out in the field, such as meter readers and home service engineers.ldquoThere is never an easy time to announce redundancies and this is a particularly dficult decision to take. But like all businesses, we face a new reality and need to adapt quickly to enable us to better-serve our customers and invest in a zero carbon future, said chief executive Stephen Fitzpatrick.Ovo said that the Covid- outbreak, which has forced many of its fieldworkers to stay at home, has accelerated changes that were already happening in the energy sector.For instance, customers are now being forced to read their own meters.ldquoWe are seeing a rapid increase in customers using digital channels to engage with us and, in our experience, once customers start to engage dferently they do not go back. As a result, we are expecting a permanent reduction in demand for some roles whilst other field-based roles are also heavily affected, Mr Fitzpatrick said.Mr Fitzpatrick was expected to share the news in a live online town hall with thousands of employees on Tuesday morning.It is a big change for the Ovo founder, who has been more used to hiring people than firing them since setting the firm up in .Already among the biggest challengers on the energy market, Mr Fitzpatrickrsquos business ballooned to become Britainrsquos second biggest energy supplier after acquiring SSE.At the time of the takeover was announced last September, Pete Wishart, MP for Perth and North Perthshire, said that he had been reassured during a meeting with SSE that there would be no job losses.Ovo will also close two offices, in Glasgow and Reading, that it acquired as part of the SSE deal and a third, in Selkirk, that joined Ovo when it rescued Spark Energy in .The staff at these sites will be moved to new offices or be allowed to work from home..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: , jobs to go after energy supplier Ovo buys SSE

title: yacht-club-takes-measures-help-stay-afloat

coronavirus crisis started to unfold.After the full lockdown, with the boats still on dry land, members have been using Skype on a near weekly basis to plan how to keep the club thriving for the foreseeable and long-term future.Former commodore Mark McClelland has urged members to take part in an online sailing race game called Virtual Regatta.One club member will be asked to take part in a Virtual Regatta e-championship against players from other Scottish clubs and then go on to a UK-wide competition.While playing the game, Fisherrow Yacht Clubparticipants also take part in a virtual Friday Night Bar get-together, enjoying a tipple in their own homes while connected to other participants through Zoom.One of the biggest losses to the club programme is the start-of-the season event called Discover Sailing, formerly known as Push the Boat Out, which was due to take place this Saturday, May .Inez Visser, club spokesperson, said: ldquoIt should have been an open day for non-members to try sailing and to look around the facilities in the club premises.ldquoDiscover Sailing has been the most important means to recruit new members in the last few years.ldquoFYC hopes to be able to members so, from that aspect, sailing can resume as soon as is permitted.ldquoIn addition,local members can come to the beach already dressed to go out on the water, this would free up space in the changing facilities for those who travel from further away.ldquoCurrently, the biggest challenge is figuring out a way to crew the club safety and race committee power boats without breach of the contamination guidelines.ldquoHowever, many resourceful solutions have been devised to protect people from contamination so FYC is hopeful a solution for watersports can be found soon.She added: ldquoWhile not sailing, the committee has been looking at research information published by the sailing umbrella body, Royal Yachting Association , which has analysed age demographics and water participation in general in the last few years.ldquoUsing the information from RYA, the club is looking forward to how its current activities and club facilities, especially club-owned boats, can be dferently managed to suit the needs of the next generation of sailors.ldquoThis includes not only Generations X, Y and Z, but also third age sailors, as the research highlighted that sailing is well suited to older people because the physical demands are not as great as many other sports.ldquoAt this time, FYC is ever mindful that the club premises are a resource, not only for the sailing club, title: superhero-primary-school-teacher-message-difference
story: Alison Blevins, a primary four teacher at the school, posted a welcome back message on social media after the Easter holidays.It read: ldquoWelcome back to the summer term. Please donrsquot feel any pressure to complete work in what are challenging circumstances. Irsquod sooner you went outside and enjoyed the good weather. Other ideas for her pictures came from the social media site Pinterest.Alison said: ldquoItrsquos just a dferent spin on it and Irsquom trying to engage with the pupils as much as possible, really.
